awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Effect of Bubbles on Magma Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Volcanoes have exerted a fascination since the dawn of civilization. Eruptions, besides their obvious associated hazards, are one of the rare expressions of the dynamics of the Earth over timescales that are easy to comprehend from our standpoint. Over the last decades, our community has recognized the importance of exsolved volatiles (gas bubbles) on the chemical and physical evolution of magmas in the shallow crust and on eruption dynamics. The complexity of volcanic processes and our inability to observe directly how magmas evolve prior and during volcanic eruptions has seriously limited our ability to predict the timing and behavior of volcanic eruptions. With this project, we propose the development of new numerical methods, complemented with fluid dynamics experiments to provide a quantitative understanding of how the exsolution of gases affects the physical properties of magmas, their chemistry (and the composition of gases released to the atmosphere) and ultimately how bubbles behave collectively and affect the behavior of magmas erupting at the Earth surface.

Magmas are multiphase systems composed of a very viscous ambient fluid (silicate melt), crystals and sometimes complemented by exsolved (immiscible) gas bubbles. In order to predict how magmas evolve before and during eruptions, we need to develop dynamic models that allow us to accurately represent the interplay between these three phases under various conditions. In this project, we plan to study first the exsolution and growth of water-rich bubbles to model their effect on chemical differentiation, i.e. how secondary gas phases such as sulfur species and CO2 partition into growing bubbles. The amount of sulfur incorporated into bubbles before an eruption is significant to quantify the impact of eruptions on climate (sulfur is a potent aerosol that affects the radiative balance in the atmosphere).  The chemistry of the exsolved gas phase and its participation in a future eruption depend on the efficiency of phase separation in magmas and the possible accumulation of gas bubbles in parts of the reservoir that are more likely to erupt (lower viscosity).  Our second task is to study the physics of phase separation, bubble-crystals-melt, more specifically to understand how the magma motion is impeded or facilitated by the presence of discrete bubbles and crystals.  Finally, once the rheology of multiphase magmas is better constrained, we plan to use these results and study how buoyant gas bubbles migrate in zoned magma reservoirs. The question we aim to answer is whether bubbles are prone to accumulate in regions of low or high crystal content and how this accumulation affects the chemistry of the gas in the bubbles and the eruptive behavior of the magma.

The results of the proposed research will have broad implications for physical volcanology, petrology, geochemistry and fluid dynamics. It will provide quantitative constraints on the state of magmas stored in shallow crustal reservoirs and also provide a better account of the effect of bubbles on magmas as they ascend to the surface during eruptions. Predictive models for the exsolution of sulfur in magmatic systems can also provide clues as to the climate impact of pre-historical large explosive eruptions (e.g. Toba, Cerro Galan). The goal of the proposed research is to provide quantitative tools and constitutive relations that will be widely available to interpret existing datasets (geochemistry of magmas, rheological experiments on magmas) and transfer this new knowledge to models of magma dynamics. Additionally, the development of new numerical methods to study multiphase fluid dynamics will impact the Computational Fluid Dynamics community and other fields in science and engineering, where particle suspensions or bubble emulsions are important (e.g. effect of fluid dynamics on biology, food processing?)

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed at understanding the evolution of magma chambers, specifically the magma chambers that can feed large explosive eruptions. The processes that lead to volcanic eruptions are complex and relatively poorly understood, they are to a large extent controlled by the mechanical properties of the magma (how it endures deformation) and the state of the magma chamber deep down in the crust. While the latter cannot be directly observed, it is possible to develop a suite of physical and numerical models that capture the essence of the evolution of these systems. In addition, resorting to analog experiments to better understand some aspect of that behavior, under controlled conditions, may also reveal important aspects that were previously unexplored. The activities in this project combined published data from field observations (records of past eruptions for example) with numerical models and laboratory experiments to better understand how the constituents of magmas (crystals, melt and sometimes gas bubbles) interact during transport and how this is reflected in the long-term behavior of the magma stored at depth, leading to eruptions.

We developed a model for how magma chambers evolve over long time scales, being subjected with replenishment of magmas from depth, deformation and possibly eruptions when the conditions allow. We found that the complex dynamic evolution of magma chambers can be mainly cast as a competition between how fast they cool, how rapidly they are replenished and how stiff the surrounding crust is as a container. We also showed that when mature magma chambers start to accumulate gas bubbles, their behavior changes dramatically, they are more difficult to destabilize for an eruption, but eruptions become also more voluminous. The outcomes of the model seem to align well with observations at diverse volcanic systems such as Quizapu (Chile) and Santorini (Greece), to cite a few.

In parallel to these large scale studies, we designed new studies to look into the resistance to deformation (viscosity) of magmas, more specifically the effect of crystals and bubbles on that resistance. While this is a mature field, we found that there are inconsistencies in these models that arise from assumptions that are unecessary. We therefore developed a corrected suite of models that match experiments better and provide a deeper understanding into these deformation processes. While this is important to understand how magmas are transported to shallower depth, it does not explain the process by which gas bubbles can separate and rise away from magma storage areas. This is important because gas bubbles provide the energy behind explosive eruptions. We therefore studied the transport of gas bubbles in magmas under different conditions, magmas that contain few crystals versus magmas that contain a large fraction of crystals. Perhaps counter-intuitively, we found that bubble transport can be significantly more efficient in the latter because of complex fluid dynamics feedbacks. The physical principles behind this finding were new at the time and have now been well-accepted and since confirmed by experiments from other groups.

Overall the funding from NSF was instrumental in allowing us to make significant contributions to understanding magmatic processes. While the intellectual merit is distilled above, it is important to note the broader impacts of this funding. The development of a framework to better understand the evolution of magmatic system is key to cast volcanic monitoring in a process-based framework. This funding also provided support to graduate students at Georgia Tech and Brown University as well as funding to support outreach programs with high schools (Atlanta) and undergraduate research internships (Leadership Alliance).
